div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No.7570 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.
Throw Steel Nibs Away!
They waste time, are costly to use, wear out, scratch, etc.
Try a "Swan" Fountain Pen.
Prices from 10/6
Sold by all Stationers and Importers in Cairo and Alexandria.
Catalogue free.
Mable, Todd & Bard, High Holborn, London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.

Weekly Express Mail Service. div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Messrs. May & Williams 160, Piccadilly, W.
THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)

div.head: EGYPT AND THE HOUSE OF COMMONS.
div.p: The Denishwai affair has again come before the House of Commons, and on this ocia- sion Mr. T. W. Rotertson. Mastapha Kamel's friend, was the originator of the discussion. Hi began by stating that the authenticity of the letter sent to Lord Cromer and translated in the White Book on Akabe was doubtod “by men of all opinions, including Mr. Edward Dicey." He thus allowed it to be inferred that the British Agency had either been the gnorant victim of a stupid hoax, which even nervous with aa little acquaintance with the Arabic language as Mr. Dicey could see through. or else Lord Cromer had deliberately cruel the letter to bolster up his assertions about the unrest in Egypt. He then turned to Mr. Findlay’s despatches on the Deni hwai affair and declared that “he was not fit to no’d office as representing the British Govern- -ment,” owing to the British Charge d'Afl tires' Opinions expressed thereir. He then went n to oriti i-e Mr.Findley’s telagram to Sir Blward Grey of July 5. That part c.l the elegrsm dealii g w'th tlis Egyptian Pie • ba* (ready lod to a great deal of discussion in tha ocal newspaper', bet ihe passage which Mr. ilobertson foond so Obn ixions was that wbsre- io Mr. Findlay dre» atteu'ion to the di*a«- Tons efleits that the agitation at home would - lead to in this oooniry. We need not analyse Mr. Robertson's speeds. The effect with whiob it has been re*e:ved in Eugland is thus Inscribed by tha "Daily Telegraph “On the very eve of tbebolidays the Secretary of State for Poreigo Afftirs had to taro and tend a member sent to Parliament as a Minis- terialist Mr. J. M. Kibertson—who leapt into an undesirable notoriety by his attaoks apon the humanity of British soldiers daring ths Boer War—has now taken the anti-British fellaheen in Egypt under his patronage. Iu Sis speech he more than hinted th at the British officer who wss killed at Deuisbwsi was a craven, aad attributed incapacity, in- humanity, and prejudice to all tha British authorities iu Egypt That sort ol thing wa said with impunity, with the sanction of Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman, and too often in imitation of him, in the days of the war in Sooth A fries, about Lord Milner, Lord Roberto, and Lord Kitchener—to eay nothing of officer*, non oommis ioned offiners, and men—without any very serious protest being raised by the responsible Lenders of the Opposition. It would have been well then, if some one in tie position of Sir Bdward Gey had risen from •he front benches on tha Breaker's left hand to utter the words whiob fell from the Poreign Secretory on Satorday: 'll they were to as- sume,' be said, 'direotly they thought that a mistake had been made, that tbeir r fficial* io general were likely to be either goilty ot moral or intelleotoal delit qutoeiea, and if they weri to assome that they had been in the wrong, and adopted that tone, they would make it impos- sible to oonduct successfully negotiations, sod certainly woold mrke it quite im| os*ib!e to conduct the business of the ‘British Empire.' These are words of ateru and sterling patriot- ism, and it is to be regretted that their anther was not at bis present chiefs elbow when be talked about 'methods of barbarism.' What does the ooontry think of it all f* The important bearing of this discussion does not lie io the various criticisms made by Mr. Robertson, with which we need not deal as they were all ably answered by Sir Edward Grey, bat in the Let that it and similar reoeot episodes are obviooely part and parcel of a scheme to sep Lord Cromer's aothority in Egypt through the instrumentality of individual members of the House of Com- mons. These gentlemen are probably quite un- conscious of the fact that theyarebeing merely used aepawne in a game of politioal intrigue Bat there ie no doubt that this is the oast. Who, for instanoe, inspired Mr. T. W. Ro- bertson to put that qoeetioo about the Kkedi- vial Mail Line and the pilgrim traffic which he asked the other night in the House of Commons t It is not improbable that Muitapha l’asha Hamel's mission to London is closely connected with thie plan of campaign, and that yonng man hae evidently a powerful becking. It ie an iqgenitAis method and is at the tame time far more dangeroos, and also, be it noted, far more praotioal than futile vapouring* about 1 Egypt a nation," eto. The persons who are engineering the whole business evidently took to heart the signi- ficance of one passage in Lord Cramer's report, where, in pointing out that the appli- ostion of , the term "benevolent despotism" t> bit eystem of government is not quite' correct because theoretically hie power* are ssbject to control, he eay* :—"In the first place, the British Agent and Cocsol-Qeoeral io Egypt is an exeontive officer of the British. Government, and it as much under the control of the Secretary of State for Poreign Affair* as any other member of the diplomatio servioe. In the reoond place, behind the Secretary of State lies the oontro1, whiob can at all timM be exercised, of the British Parliament and of British public opinion. In the third pleoe, the absolute freedom allowed to the loci! Pres* in Egypt oonstitotes in iteelf a guarantee of no small value that no real abuts of power would be allowed to past unnotioed. If, of lata years, tha ooutrol of the Secretary of State has cut been very aotirely exercised, and if Egyptian tffsirt have received hot little attention in Parliament, the reason, I venture to think, it that no eeriont occasion baa arisen for ibe exercise of ‘he powers which, although they may fur a time be atloired to remain dormant, nr questionably exist The poeeible danger in the tutore for Bgyptliet, a* it would appear to me, not to moch in any serious risk of abuse of power by any individual on the spot, a* io the ooeortenee of tome incident 1 whiob may lead to tha aotive exercise of the d irtoaot power* vested in authorities at a 1 i i stance. British poblio opinion it not always very well informed on the affairs and precise cmditions of foreign oouotriea. It is ooo- olivable that at tome future time, well- I intentiooed efforts to foster somewhat too * rapidly the growth of telfgoveroiog inetitu- 1 tiont might remit in the re establishment, in 1 mother form, of personal power of the kind which, at no vary remote date, did so mooh f harm to the oouotry, whiob hat left behind it * habits and tradition* at yet far from being ' extinot...." 1 This propbeoy of Lord Cromer began to be 1 fulfilled only a few weeks after the Report had I been published, and the Deoiabwai affair at * O toe led to ' the active exeroise of the dormant II powers vested in authorities »t a distanos." e Fortunately 8ir B Iward Grey 1* a firm believer 1 ii the need for oon'inuity in fireign policy and I ba iro* able to close the fl wd-gatm of the Litt'e II Englanders' criticism for a time by hi* state- * meot si to the dangers of Egyptian fanaticism. r But the oatbnret of Mr. R nberteoa shows that n on appeal to the neel for retioenoe has any D uffoot, and when the Home meets again next '■ October we may expeot to fi id Egypt it beoom- '• ing a* favourite a subj-ct for Radical criticism 1 as South Africa.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: The Plague
Breakout of bubonic plague is reported Cases reported here and another from Suez.
1895 Emigrants.
It is announced that the total number of assigned emigrants, who have arrived of late Egypt, amounts to 600.
New Steamship Line.
A new British line of steamers is to run between London and Mombasa, touching at Port j Said, Suez and Port Sudan.
Motor Accident.
The motor of an automobile belonging to a Cairo Omnibus Company exploded at 6 a.m. on Friday. Nobody was injured.
Gambling Hell Raided.
A gambling den was raided by the police at Boulac the other night, and the paraphemalia gambling and the money were confiscated.
Imperial Anniversary.
There will be a reception on the 18th inst. at the Austro Hungarian Diplomatic Agency and Consulate General at Cairo on the occassion on of the birthday of the Experor Francis Joseph.
See Medical Attendance.
A committee, composed of leading members of the native Masonic Lodges at Alexandria, have secured the services of four doctors and midwife for attending indigeat patients at night free of charge.
Murdered While Asleep.
It is reported from Dessonk that a certain Mohamed Aly Saleh, of tho village of El | Mandoura, has been murdered while asleep in his field. Two men have been arrested on suspicion of the crime.
Tabah and Janet

The "Temps” remarks'; "The Tabah inicident has had the excellent assault for England of finally disposing of the question of the Sinai Peninsula. The Janet incident cannot fail to have an exactly similar assult for France.”
The Egyptian Prose.

"Al Lewa” and ‘ Al Zaher," who have been qualifying one another because the latter newspaper declared that Mustapha Pasha Kamel and received a subvention for conducting his Oenishwai campaign in London, have now calmed down as intherces have been brought o teat our both these papers in order to stop inconvenient revelations.
Anglo-Eyptian Officials.

The number of Britishers whom it has been decided to engage this year for service in the Egyptian Government amounts to forty eight, 16 of whom are required for the Ministry of Public Instruction, 6 for the Public Works Department as engineers, and 8 for the Public Health Department, including two mechanics to take charge of surgical instruments.
San Stefano Casino.

The following is the programme of the week at San Stefano: — Tuesday afternoon, grand concert Thursday afternoon, vocal and instrumental concert ; Friday, instrumental concert and children's ball at 5.30 p.m. (chocolate will be given to children of subscribers); Saturday, night fete with co-operatiqn of Hellenic Philharmonic Society, illumination and fireworks.
Arrested for Carrying a Newspaper.

Nouri Bey, secretary to H. B. Mukhtar Pasha, has telegraphed from Alexandria to the family at Mahmoud Arif, who was recently arrested in Constantinople, stating that Mahmond Bey has been acquitted. H.I.M. the Saltan issued orders that the Bey’s wife in Cairo should be informed of her husband's release. Arif Bey was taken into custody, states "Al Moayad” because a copy of “A1 Mokattam" was found in Constantinople among his belongings. The "seditious" paper, it is thought, had been surreptitiously placed in Mahmoud Bey's bag, before his departure, by a relative of his who is on bad terms with him owing to some domestic difference.
Mehemot Ali.

Mehemet Ali did not learn to read until he was forty five years of age, but long before that (says the "Westminster Gaiette") his rigour of mind had established his dynasty upon the throne of Egypt, Macedonian by birth, his history is that of an extraordinary rise from poverty and obscurity. He began life as a tobacconist, and then, turning to the army, displayed an uncommon aptitude for leadership. In Egypt he faced with distinction the armies of Napoleon, and established himself in such favour that in 1806 he was made Viceroy by universal acclaim and had his appointment confirmed by the Sultan. The black stain upon a memory which is in the main one of a man extraordinarily in advance of the thought of those about him is the trechorous murders of the Mamelukes who refused to recognise his secession to power. Soon after this dread deed he was master of Egypt, and defied his Sultan in Syria, although the nominal monarch was able to recover his country when backed by the might of European Powers. Egypt under his enlightened administration broke the sleep of centuries, only to fall back again in the bauds of weaker rulers.
Summer Amusements.

There are many people who seek a means of occupying their leisure time in the summer. The Berlitz Schools of Cairo (1, rue Sharia Kamel) and Alexandria (12, rue Rosette) procure for persons of all ages and conditions, a most useful and agreeable diversion. The lessons given there are interesting and varied, and are really an intellectual relaxation. A free trial lesson will permit everyone to assure himself of this fact. [ADVT].

div.head: THE SULTAN'S HEALTH. CAUSE OF ILLNESS. CONDITION IMPROVING
div.p: CONSTANTINOPLE August 11.
The Sultan was absent from the Salamlik yesterday. It is reported that it will be necessary for him to undergo an operation. LITER
The German surgeon, Dr. Bergmann, has boon summoned here, but it is believed that the Sultan's chief trouble is hemorrhoidis, or a cognate malady, extremely painful, but not dangerous. (Reuter)
Constantinople, August 11. !,
The condition of the Sultan is serious. He is suffering from urethritis. An operation will probably be necessary. (Havas)
Constantinople, August 12.
The Sultan's condition has slightly improved enabling him to attend to business. The press has been forbidden to mention his illness. (Reuter)
Constantinople, August 12.
The Sultan's condition is improving. (H.)

div.head: HELOUAN ROADS.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette." Sir, —I noticed in yesterday’s issne of the a ;n "Gazette" a paragraph on the subject of the purchase of the Cafe San Giovanni by the Al Hayst Hotel Company. I should like to take the opportunity of bringing to the notice of the Public Works Department the neglect of the Nile road by the Janzim Service. We have a steam roller at work on the roads in the town, although there is no apparent need, while the urgent necessity for improving the only route from Helouan to the Nile is absolutely overlooked. The road is in a most disgraceful state, and it is impossible for carriages to pass down the road. It is the only excursion route in Helouan and the main road to Bedreschin. I cannot understand why the authorities have persistently neglected this most essential part of the communications of Helouan,and it is sincerely to be hoped that immediate efforts will be taken to put it in order before the coming season. I am, etc., Rud. Springer. Hotel Bean Rivage, Ramleh.

div.head: BAND PERFORMANCE.
div.p: By kind permission of Lt Col. C J. Markham and officers,the band of the 1st Battalion King's Royal Rifles will perform the following selection of music at the Esbekieh Gardens to-morrow (Tuesday) from 9 to 11 p.m.

March-Oh,you women-Linoke. Overture-French Comedy- Keler Beta Reminiscences of Sullivan- Arr. Winter bottom. Placca de Concert- L’Oiseau du Bois- Le Thiere Corpl. H. Arnold. Polonaise- Masken- Faust. Valse- Donau Wellen- Ivanovich Selection- II Trovatore-Verdi Cake Walk- The Brooklyn-Thurban Regimental March.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Mors liner Menes arrived here yesterday morning from Liverpool, via Gibraltar, Algiers, and Malta with passengers, mails and general cargo. The M.M. steamer Niger, from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday and is due here tomorrow.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL
div.p: CARIO. Built in 1904. Modern House. Splendid situation.Electric Light Lift. Pensions P.T.,50. Arrangements for families. Rooms and breakfast P.T.25.----Meals a la Cart 30789-36-11-008

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: BULEKELY (near Alexzandria.) Half way to San Stefano. RAMLEH'S FASHIONABLE HOTEL PATRONISED BY THE ELITE. Vall Pensions P.T. 50 a day. Visiters from Caire all the at Sidi-Gaber Statien. 24-11-06 C.AQUILINA,proprietor.

div.head: SITUATION IN EGYPT
div.p: DISCUSSION IN PARLIMENT. DENISHWAI AGAIN. ATTACK ON MR.FINDLAY. SIR E. GREY'S SPEECH. Egypt has again come before the attention of the House of Commons and on the very eve of the session when on Saturday week the Prime Minister moved the adjournment of the House, MR. J. M. Robertson, the member for Tyneside and the friend of Mustspns Pasha Kamel, procedded to discuss the Denishwai affray, stating that the authenticity of the letter sent to Lord Cromer on the subject of Moslem designs was doubted by men of all opinions, including Mr.Edward Dicey. All the principal officials and officers in Egypt were now absent on leave, and there was not the slightest sign that a fanatical outbreak was feared. In his view, the House need no longer be bound by the appeal of the Foreign Secretary to refrain from discussing the Denishwai in- cident. He did not charge the officers con- cerned with anything more than indiscretion, but he certainly thought the charge of pre- meditation brought against the natives was not only false but absurd. If a number of aliens had come into an English village and had shot at pigeobs and poultry, probably coming into contact with gamekeepers, there would have been a most violent affray. In this case he thought no murder took place, and there had been a gross attempt by an official in the report to put a false aspect on the case.

Mr. Findlay Criticised. Mr.Findlay had said that that a British jury would have found six of the men guilty of murder. That was a nonsensical proposition. The officier died not on account of his wounds. but because he ran five miles under an Egyp- tian sun to bring assistance. If this was really Mr.Findlay's opinion he was not fit to hold office as representing the British Government. and if it was not his opinion he was equally unfit. It was this same official who had been allowed to deliver a presumptuous judgement upon the House of Commons for raising a word of deprecation.

The Execution at Denishwai was nothing else than an act of revenge for a display of want of due respect towards a body of British officers. He urged the aboli- tion of the special tribunal in Egypt. Court martial action ought not to be permitted in times of peace. The great deeds of Lord Cromer should not be allowed to hold him guiltless in permitting a lawless revenge on these natives. Mr. Molteno did not think the "man on the spot" should be allowed to be the judge of the policy and principle of the British govern- ment. He objected to special tribunals of the kind appointed in Egypt to deal with the case of native insubordination.

Sir E. Grey's Speech. Sir E. Grey said Mr. Molteno had corrected an omission. In referring to the appeal which he (Sir E. Grey) made to the House on a previous occasion not to discuss this question, Mr.Molteno quite rightly pointed out that he (sir E. Grey) had asked the House not to discuss this until it had the information before it. (Hear, hear.) That was really the particular point of his appeal. This tribnnal in Egypt was composed of the highest judges. It had come to a decision after taking evi- dence for three days in a very serious case, and if the House of Commons had rushed to an assumption and been unwilling to wait for further information the effect must have been most prejudicial, and must have conveyed an impression abroad that the moment anything occurred which the House of Commons did not quite understand it would at once as- sume thatthe officials on the spot were to blamer(Cheers) He had to thank the House for having responded as it did to the appeal whichh he made.

Restlessness In Egypt. The first information which he got. he would not say of the fanaticism. but of the restlessness in Egypt. was in the early days when this country was in occupation of certain islands belonging to the Sultan. because of the dith- cnlties which had arisen with Turkey on the Macedonian question. That began to have its effect on Egypt. When they had a conflict of that kind they might be quite sure that it was bound to have a certain effect on the .\foln-medan races under British rule or in the countries under British occupation. There was the further difficulty about the frontier question. Undoubtedly he thought that anybody who read the Blue Book on the frontier incident would see it was natural and inevitable that there should bore tless-‘ ness and unsettled feeling in BN9! about_ these occurrences. He thought that in time, that would pass. it had been necessary to increase the garrison. and that was done sime time ago. Undoubtedly if that feeling was to spread they would have totske further measures to increase the garrison still more. It was that step which he wished to avoid by deprocating dircussion in that House.

Mr. Findlay Defended The nature of Mr. Robertson's speech made it necessary for him to say some words about the personal matter of Mr. Findlay. He regrlttnd much ofthe largoage used by Mr. Robertson. (Ministerial cheers.) Surely if their officials had done wrong they could criticise them without calling them cowardly officials. (Hear, hear.) Mr.Robertson: I did not apply that term to Mr.Findlay Sir E. Grey: No, the hon. member applied it generally. Mr. Robertson: I only spoke about Mr. Findlay because in a letter he made an attack upon this House. Sir B Gray said that there were other expres- sions which were equally unfortunate. If they were to assume. directly they thought that a mistake had been made, that their oﬂicials in general were likely to be either guilty of moral or intellectual deficiencies, and if they were to assume that they had been in the wrong. and adopted that tone. they would make it impos- slblu to conduct successfully negotiations, and certainly would make it quite impossible to conduct the business of the British Empire. (Cheers).

Mr. Findlay defended Coming to the question of Mr. Findlay. he thought that Mr. Robertson had mistaken the nature of this particular telegram with which he found so much fault. and which, he could only think. was, in part. responsible for the tone of much of his speech. He thought if Mr. Robertson had not regarded it as a provocative telegram. perhaps his own language would have been softer than it was. (Hear. hear.) He did not think the telegram was intended to be provocative by Mr. Findlay. He did not take it as a criticism at all of the House of Com- mons. He took it as a statement of fact, which Mr. Findlay said it was his duty to If he (Sir B. Gray) made a statement or used lan- guageiu that House which had a prejudicial effect abroad. he would expect the officials in the diplomatic Jervice to inform him what that effect had been, and he would consider it was their duty to do so. Mr. Findlay was per- forming quits rightly his duty in saying what the effect of certain proceedings in the House of Commons, as a matter of fact. would be on the spot. Mr. Findlay was bound to say that.

Danger of Criticism. One of the difficulties of governing the British Empire was that criticism of what was done in various parts of the Empire was always liable to have a disturbing eﬂbnt upon the spot.That was not always the paramount cousi- dsration. but the oﬂiciala on the spot ought to let them know what it was. because it was one of the elements which they must take into account in forming a judgment. He might feel it his duty to use language in tbellousa which he might know would have an unfortunate affect in a particular country abroad.but which for gravar eousideratiousbstbouglit it neces- my to use. He would expect that the officials would let him know what was the effect of the speech. but he would reserve to himself the decision as to whether that should belbbe paramount consideration or not.

The Telegram He thought that Mr. Findlay was bound to state what was the particular effect on Egypt of discussions in that House, and to leave it for the House to decide whether the effect he pointed out would be regaurded as the par- amount consideration. Mr. Findlay's whole career made them feel that he was a man of character and ability. and that he would rise in the Diplomatic Service. and would do good public service abroad. That did not dispose of the telegram. Mr. Robertson raised the point whether he (Sir B. Gray) ought to have pub- lislied it. He knew the telegram was not sent for publication. but be had promised the fullest information. and he wished to subcdit it as little as possible. (Ministerial cheers.) He thought it right to publish that telegram in order to give tba_House the whole truth of the matter. and. having published it, to leave it to them to consider whsh weight it. ought to have. He would ask 1 House to take this telegram as a statamsnt of fact, and not as a criticism cf the House. (Hear, hear.)

The Denishwal Trial. As to the case itself. Mr. Molteuo asked about the evidence He had promised that the evidence should be published when received, and that would be done. It was quite impos- sible in scars of that kind. which had been tried by the highest tribunals in Egypt. that the case should be retried in that. House with some bon. members for the defence and some for the prosecution. (Cheers) That tribunal corresponded to what. over here would be a tribunal composed of the Home Secretary. the Lord Chief J nation. and other people qualiﬁed to trrcriminal oasaa He did not see how there c,_m|d 5, guy lggal appeal, but there should be some prerogative of mercy. With regard to the holdiugof executions in public. be thought that at best it was a very doubtful expedient. and never exceptional cases~—(Miuisterial cheers) and as to fl igging in public, he should say. "Never." (Loud cheers.)

The Sentence. Then Mr. Robertson raised the question of the nature of the punishment this Court might inflict. The decree relating to these matters was passed. eleven years ago, and this was the first serious occasion upon wlii ad been brought into operation. I' was’ natural that certain defects in the decree should be disclosed. They should be remedied. and Lord Cromer. after review'ng the whole proceeding. had dealt with them. and had suggested that it might be well to have certain modifiratious carried out in the decree. The e modiﬁcations would certainly receive the strong support of his Msjrsty's Government (Cheers) He agreed entirely with Lord Crmner's interesting ms- mnra-zdum reviewing the whole case. ' 0 question of responsibility in Egypt was a very difﬁcult one to decido.The government of Egypt was complicated, but Lord Crcnier interfered as little as possible in matters of administra- tion. As regaurded certian thing he was ab- solutely powerful, especially in regaurd to European intrests. In the second place, all questions of Mahomedaniam were outside his control altogether, and all criminal matters were dealt with by judges who were removable and were independent.

Egypt a crown Colony ! He believed that anyone studying the machinery of Egyptian Government on paper would come to the conclusion that it was a moat unworkable system. Lord Cromer had. however. made ii. work. but still the machinery of administration was complicated. If it was desired to amplify it. Egypt might be turned into a Crown Colony; but he put such a change as that one side as not being practical politics. The other alternative would be to leave it to native rule, which would soon be Turkish rule.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H.E. Salch Pasha Sabit. President of the Native Court of Appeal. Cairo. returned from Europe today by the Austrian steamer on his return from Europe.

The holy of the late Mohamed Pasha Cbsrif will be transported in a few days to Cairo, where the interment will take place in the family vault. The late Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affilra succumbed in Paris to an intestinal cancer. against which the eﬁorta of the greatest physicians proved un- availing.

Mr. Wuuderliob. German Consul at Alex- andria, is leaving today for Cairo, whence, after a short stay. be will proceed on Wednes- day to Port Said to embark ‘on the D. O. A. liner Harm; for Europe. on two months' leave of absence.
During Mr. Wumlsrlich's absence, the German Consulate willba in charge of Vice- Cousul Baron Werner von Grunan.
Mr. Janet des Combos. manager of the Alexandria and Ramleb Railway Company and the Alexandria Tramway Company, is off to Switzerland for a holiday.
Major A. C. Fox, R.A.M.C., has arrived in Egypt, and been taken on the strength of this command.
Captain R. G. B. Jslfrsyr. lat Royal Dublin Fusiliers. and Liant. W. R. Meredith, 2nd Royal lnniskilling Fusiliers, have been granted leave of absenee.
Dr. Evangelo D. Mavroyannis has been authorised to practise in Egypt.

Mr. John Mackinnon Robertson, who has come so prominently forward in Parliament in connection with the Denishwal agitation, is a native of Brodrick. Isle of Arran. and is married to an Amsriciu lady. He was educated at Stirling. Scotland. but left school an. very early age. 13. to take up the journalistic pro- fession. At the age of 82 he joined the staff of the "Edinburg Evening News" as leader writer, and six years later went to London to join Mr. Bradlaugh's "National Reformer." He edited that journal from Mr. Bradlauglfs death in 1891 till its stoppage in 1893. He then started the "Free Review" and edited it till 1895. In that year he stood as Independent Radical candidate for N ortbamptou. He pro- carded on a lecturing tour in the United States in I397-8_ and went to South Africa in 1900 to investigate martial law. etc.. in Cape Colony and Natal. sending letters thereon signed "Scrutator" to the "Morning Leader." In 1903 be was chosen by the Tynesidu Liberal Association as its caudida'e for the next elec- tion. and be now represents that constituency. Mr. Robertson has written a great deal. Among his publicatitns a:e. Modern Humanists ; Essays toward a Critical Method; Buckle and his Critics. Montaigne and Shakespeare; The Saxon and the Celt; The Dynamics of Kell- gion ; History of Free Thought; Christianity and Mythology ; Studies in Religious Fallacy ; Introduction to English Politics ;'l‘be Fallacy of Saving; The Eight Hours Question ; Patriotism and Empire ; Wrecking the Empire; AShort History of Christianity; Letters on Reasoning ; Pagan Christa ; Criticisms ; Essays in Ethics and Sociology ; The Case for Free Trade. etc.
Instrument Concerts
Every Night
On the Verandah of the
WINDSOR, HOTEL
Alexandria
From 6 to 12 p.m.
5 O'clock Tea Served on Verandah.

div.head: YESTERDAYS'S REGATTA "HENLEY" AT RAS-EL-TIN
div.p: The painter in quest of Oriental colouring would have found ample material for his talents yesterday afternoon on that historically interesting promontory of Ras-E|—'I‘in, with its Vice«Regal Palace and ccininanding ligbtlnure. Indeed it was a matter of reg-.et expressed by more than one person that no one was then: to convey on to an enduring canvass seine traits at least of the splendour of the picture— -to be kept as a souvenir of a red-letter day in the annals of Alcxandrian nautical .eirr.‘ea. ' Egypt's sun. journeying through leavens of the deepest bloc. ﬂooded a scene in which every has of the rainbow was markedly vivid ; a scene which. viewed from the terrace of the Khedivial Yacht Club. lay spread bslorp the eye in all its wealth of imagery. To the lefr. the embankment which has been built out on to the water, was gor- geous with the flags of nations-Egyptian, British. French. German. ltaliau—l:r if yes- terday’s was a sporting event. it was no la" successfully ademonstratibn of international goodwill. Beneath this gaudy panoply a fashionable throng. mastering their hundreds. had assembled long bef-ire the opening of the fete. At the close, the prizes were gracefully awarded by Mme Girard, the charming wite of the much esteemed French Consul.

The results of the events follow:-- ARAB ROWING-BOATS FOR THE TWO ROWERS: I. CLUB ; I. E. SEEGER ; II. MAAS ; III. WOLFMANN FANCY BOAT RACE: John Chini. SWIMMING RACE: Jansen. GREASY POLE: Gartner WATER JOUSTS 1st set. Rowing Club; 2nd Deutscher Sport Verein ; 3rd Canottiere, Club. OBSTACLE RACE: E.Seeger. TUG OF WAR: Canottiere Club. -2 out of three tags.

After the sports, the members of the fan clubs. forming into tive battalions and headed by their stands a, and bearing Chinese lanterns. marched into the town to the strains oftbe immortal Mattobichs. to the intense delight of the Arab population.
They all repaired to the Windsor Hotel, where an excellent dinner had been prepared for them by the Mr. A. V. Millingen.
